title: 108_s377
content:
The Act is titled the "Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., Commemorative Coin Act of 2003". It includes findings related to the commemoration. Congress finds that Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. dedicated his life to securing the Nation's principles of liberty and justice, spearheaded the civil rights movement in the 1950s and 1960s, delivered his famous "I Have A Dream" speech at the March on Washington in 1963, and championed nonviolence. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. advocated nonviolent resistance to end segregation and racial discrimination, winning the 1964 Nobel Peace Prize. Americans should honor his legacy to achieve equality. Efforts are ongoing to preserve his personal papers for future study at the Library of Congress. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS.

The Secretary of the Treasury will mint $1 silver coins weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, containing 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender.

SEC. 4. SOURCES OF BULLION.

Silver for minting coins will be obtained from various sources, including stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act.

SEC. 5. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of the coins minted under this Act will reflect Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.'s human rights legacy. Each coin will feature a value designation, the year "2003", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with various entities and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF COINS.

Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single designated facility of the United States Mint. The Secretary is authorized to issue these coins only during a one-year period starting on January 15, 2004. SEC. 7. SALE OF COINS.

The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and a $10 surcharge per coin will be included in all sales. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales will be promptly paid to the Library of Congress for purchasing and maintaining historical documents related to Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.
